Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "Summer Symposium in Real Analysis 39" that will be held June 8-13, 2015, on the campus of St. Olaf College. This conference is the thirty-ninth in a series that has evolved into one of the major venues internationally for the presentation of research developments in real analysis and related areas.

The scientific program for the 2015 Symposium covers a broad array of topics, ranging from regularity issues for partial differential equations to Morse-Sard-type results, from questions in geometric measure theory to topics in combinatorial and set theoretic analysis. The featured speakers are Marianna Csornyei (University of Chicago), Alexander Olevskii (University of Tel Aviv), and Miklos Laczkovich (Eotovos Lorand University). The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work. Proceedings of the Symposium will be made available on-line.

Conference web site: http://www.stolaf.edu/analysis/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summer Symposium in Real Analysis 39 was one of a long series of research conferences in real analysis. A main goal of this symposium is to encourage collaboration and the sharing of the best of techniques and ideas among the world-wide community of real analysts. The previous two symposia have been in Prague (2014) and Sao Paolo (2013) while the 2016 symposium will be held in Sarajevo this coming June.  

 

Our Plenary Speakers were chosen to reflect the breadth and depth of current research. Laczkovich's (Budapest) talk on Kakeya type constructions was spectacular, but contained a small error in one case. That "error" opened the door to a great deal more work that is still on going with groups in Chicago, Budapest and Warwick. Mauldin's (NSA and North Texas) talk was sponsored by a grant from GOOGLE and concerned the Scottish Book Problems. Discussions prior to the symposium uncovered a solution to #157 that was not known prior to last January. A paper about #157 will appear this spring and the new edition of the Scottish Book appeared last fall. Olevskii's (Tel Aviv) talk on his quasicrystal solution brought several harmonic analysts to his lecture. This is a very important result on which he's now lectured internationally many times since the symposium. Csornyei (Chicago) has developed a strong school of real analysis centered at the University of Chicago; her talk showed how classical theorems about tangency and differentiability generalized to deeper setting. Buczolich (Budapest) displayed a deep understanding of geometry, classical real analysis and ergodic theory in his talk on a program shared with the Paris school of real analysis.

 

Another main goal of the symposium is to introduce young people to research in real analysis. Two of the younger folks (Virginia and St. Petersburg) have begun an active collaboration and the beginnings of a paper. They met at the symposium for the first time. Too, although several of the Mexican analysts attended the Sao Paolo symposium, this is the first time in North America that we have attracted researchers from the Mexican school.

 

One of the problems presented at the Research Problem Session was solved at the conference by a Chicago graduate student in a very elegant way. He is writing his solution up as a note.

 

We hired undergraduates to help with the organization of the symposium and made all of the conference activities and talks available to them. These eight students applied for the position and were chosen from St. Olaf College, the University of Chicago and Carleton College. This exposure to research allows these students to see first hand the nature of a research community and how it operates. Of the four senior students, three will attend PhD programs in mathematics next fall and the fourth in Chemistry. The remaining four will continue their undergraduate work for another year or two.
